answer.statement: IDs and classes are both selectors in CSS
answer.explanation: ID is used to identify a single element while a class can be used to identify multiple elements.
answer.example: The ID selector is preceded by a hash sign (#) while the class selector is preceded by a full stop (.)
answer.illustration: A good way to remember this is a class is a type of item and the id is the unique name of an item on the page.

answer.statement: DOCTYPE is an abbreviation for DOCument TYPE and is always associated with a DTD (Document Type Definition)
answer.explanation: DOCTYPE declaration is required for webpages and send the user agent information on what document type to expect ie what version of html specifications your document respects.
answer.example: Once a user agent has recognized a correct DOCTYPE, it will trigger the no-quirks mode matching this DOCTYPE for reading the document. If a user agent doesn't recognize a correct DOCTYPE, it will trigger the quirks mode.
answer.illustration: The DOCTYPE declaration for the HTML5 standards is <!DOCTYPE html>.

answer.statement: Event delegation is a technique for listening to events where you delegate a parent element as the listener for all of the events that happen inside it.
answer.explanation: Rather than having an event listener on each child element, a single common parent element listens and responds to event triggered on any of its child nodes.
answer.example: You can target a button child by adding an event listener on the parent div containing the button as a child element.
answer.illustration: This is very useful when dynamically adding new elements like buttons  or li etc. to a page via DOM manipulation/after the page has been loaded.
